annotations.normalized_text: Dynamic Documents with R and knitr

tweets.text:
9/ üìö Resources: Dive deeper into advanced R Markdown with these books and articles:
‚Ä¢"R Markdown: The Definitive Guide" by Yihui Xie et al. 
‚Ä¢"Dynamic Documents with R and knitr" by Yihui Xie
‚Ä¢"R Markdown Cookbook" by Yihui Xie et al. 
#rstats

8/ üåê Hosting and Sharing: Publish your R Markdown documents on:
‚Ä¢GitHub Pages for static websites
‚Ä¢RStudio Connect for Shiny apps and interactive content
‚Ä¢RPubs for simple sharing of R Markdown output
#rstats

7/ üöÄ Output Formats: Expand your reach by outputting to multiple formats:
‚Ä¢Use bookdown for books, thesis, or large documents
‚Ä¢Create presentations with xaringan or ioslides
‚Ä¢Generate websites with blogdown or distill
#rstats

6/ üîÑ Reproducible Workflows: Improve your reproducibility with:
‚Ä¢Cache code chunks for faster document rendering
‚Ä¢Use knitr::spin() for literate programming
‚Ä¢Employ RStudio projects for organized and shareable workspaces
#rstats

5/ üìä Parameterized Reports: Create reusable, customizable R Markdown documents by:
‚Ä¢Using params in the YAML header
‚Ä¢Passing parameters via rmarkdown::render()
‚Ä¢Employing conditional statements in your code
#rstats

4/ üé® Custom Templates: Stand out with your own R Markdown templates:
‚Ä¢Create your own HTML, PDF, or Word templates
‚Ä¢Use YAML header options for customization
‚Ä¢Use rmarkdown::render() for programmatic rendering
‚Ä¢Share templates with others via packages
#rstats

3/ üí´ Interactive Elements: Bring your documents to life with:
‚Ä¢Shiny for reactive, interactive content
‚Ä¢plotly for interactive graphs and charts
‚Ä¢DT for searchable, sortable tables
‚Ä¢crosstalk to link interactive widgets
‚Ä¢leaflet for interactive maps
#rstats

2/ üìê Advanced Formatting: Enhance your R Markdown documents with:
‚Ä¢LaTeX for mathematical notation
‚Ä¢HTML/CSS for custom styling
‚Ä¢Tables with kableExtra or gt for enhanced visuals
‚Ä¢Incorporating citations with BibTeX
‚Ä¢Including external images or files
#rstats

1/ üí° Advanced R Markdown: Tips, Tricks, and Best Practices üìù Learn how to create impressive, dynamic, and reproducible documents with R Markdown. We'll cover advanced formatting, interactive elements, and custom templates. Follow along! #rstats #AdvancedR #RMarkdown https://t.co/HjBHBj1Fk3

Updates in dplyr 1.1.0.

Bye bye `group_by()`, hello `.by`: https://t.co/OPIaniIcVu

urls.description: Group ‚ÄúSummary‚Äù computations such as ‚Äòsum(1:3, 4, na.rm=5, NA, 7, na.rm = LL)‚Äô now give an error instead of either ‚Äò17‚Äô or ‚ÄòNN‚Äô for ‚ÄòLL‚Äô true or false, as proposed by Ivan Krylov on the R-devel mailing

tweets.text:
2023-04-21: CHANGES IN R-devel BUG FIXES 

 * 

 Group ‚ÄúSummary‚Äù computations such as ‚Äòsum(1:3, 4, na.rm=5, NA, 7, na.rm = LL)‚Äô now give an error instead of either ‚Äò17‚Äô or ‚ÄòNN‚Äô for ‚ÄòLL‚Äô true or false, as proposed by Ivan Krylov on the R-devel‚Ä¶ https://t.co/Y5IORSwJdw

9/ üìö Resources: Want to dive deeper into R's OOP systems? Check out these books:

"Advanced R" by Hadley Wickham
"R Programming for Data Science" by Roger D. Peng
"R Object-oriented Programming" by Kelly Black

#RStats #OOP #DataScience

8/ ü§î Which system to use? S3 is suitable for small projects and quick prototypes. S4 is a better choice for larger projects and package development. R6 is recommended for complex projects requiring mutable objects and advanced OOP features. #RStats  #OOP #DataScience
7/ üõ†Ô∏è Example - R6: Define a "Person" class and a "greet()" method. #R6 #OOP #RStats #DataScience https://t.co/XupuVg9crX

6/ üöÄ R6 System: A modern and powerful OOP system, R6 introduces reference classes, making it easier to work with mutable objects. Create R6 classes with the "R6::R6Class()" function. #R6 #OOP #RStats #DataScience
5/ üõ†Ô∏è Example - S4: Define a "Person" class and a "greet()" method. #S4 #OOP #RStats #DataScience https://t.co/jo41jXy3x5

4/ üî¨ S4 System: A more formal and strict OOP system, S4 introduces class definitions, validation, and multiple dispatch. Create classes using "setClass()" and methods with "setMethod()". #S4 #OOP #RStats #DataScience

3/ üõ†Ô∏è Example - S3: Define a simple "Person" class and a "greet()" generic function.
#S3 #OOP #RStats #DataScience https://t.co/yUk1Qjqt2x

2/ üîé S3 System: The most widely used and simplest OOP system in R. Create classes using "class()" and define generic functions with "UseMethod()". S3 is informal, making it both easy to use and prone to errors. #S3 #OOP #RStats #DataScience

1/ üèóÔ∏è Mastering R's Object-Oriented Programming: S3, S4, and R6 Systems ü§ñ Let's unravel the mysteries of R's object-oriented systems, and learn how to create flexible and reusable code! Join the thread for insights and examples. #rstats #OOP #datascience https://t.co/5vXeE6a775

‚Ä¢ "R Graphics Cookbook" by Winston Chang
#rstats #datascience

8/ üìä skimr: Get quick and informative summaries of your data with the skimr package. It generates easy-to-read summaries that can help you understand your data better and faster. #rstats #datascience

7/ üéõÔ∏è config: Manage your project configurations with ease. The config package allows you to set up and switch between different environments (e.g., development, production), streamlining your workflow. #rstats #datascience

6/ üìà ggplot2 extensions: Extend ggplot2's capabilities with packages like ggrepel, gganimate, and ggforce. These add-ons can help you create more informative and visually appealing plots. #ggplot2 #DataViz
#rstats #datascience

5/ üåê httr: Ever needed to work with APIs in R? The httr package makes it a breeze to send HTTP requests and handle the response, making it a powerful tool for web scraping and API interactions. #rstats #datascience
4/ üß∞ glue: Say hello to a more convenient way of working with strings! The glue package makes it easy to create and format strings with embedded R expressions. #rstats #datascience

3/ üì¶ janitor: Clean and preprocess your data with ease. Functions like clean_names() and remove_empty() make your data tidier and more manageable. Say goodbye to messy data frames! #rstats #datascience

2/ üßô‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Functions: R has many built-in functions that often go unnoticed. Here are a few:
‚Ä¢with(): Apply expressions to a data frame without using the $ operator
‚Ä¢switch(): Simplify conditional expressions
‚Ä¢https://t.co/lE0038qpVh(): Call a function with arguments in a list

We have a hit a milestone on this nascent project üå±  v0.1 has been sent to local authorities nationwide üè¥Û†ÅßÛ†Å¢Û†Å≥Û†Å£Û†Å¥Û†Åø Supporting more evidence-based, transparent, and consistent cycle network planning, highlighting the huge potential for bikes and e-bikes across Scotland üö≤üö≤üö≤ https://t.co/7jHPvp9Qrj

urls.description: Read more about 'Reference Manager for Overleaf with CiteDrive' | CiteDrive - BibTeX-supported citation and reference management for your bibliographies on Overleaf and RStudio

tweets.text: üìö No more citation stress! Discover @CiteDrive for RStudio, the easy-to-use tool for managing your bibliography and inserting references into R Markdown documents. With #CiteDrive, you can effortlessly streamline your citation process. Learn more at https://t.co/kAqeJZ5OcB.‚Ä¶ https://t.co/Ba877qybBm https://t.co/7D4I9PSLgR
